revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} {{More citations needed|date=April 2018}} {{Politics of Burkina Faso}} [[Burkina Faso]] has good relations with the European Union,<ref>[https://eeas.europa.eu/delegations/burkina-faso_en/4352/Burkina%20Faso%20and%20the%20EU Delegation of European Union to Burkina Faso Webpage.]</ref> African<ref>[https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/africa/bf-forrel.htm Global Security Article on Burkina Faso's Foreign relations.]</ref> and certain Asian countries. France, the former colonial power, in particular, continues to provide significant aid and supports [[Blaise Compaoré|Compaoré's]] developing role as a regional powerbroker.
According to the U.S. State Department, "[[Burkina Faso-United States relations|U.S. relations with Burkina Faso]] are good but subject to strains in the past because of the Compaoré government's past involvement in arms trading and other sanctions-breaking activity."<ref>{{StateDept |url=https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2834.htm}}</ref> Burkina Faso cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan in May 2018 ([[Timeline of diplomatic relations of the Republic of China|being the most populous state to do so in the 21st century]]) and the foreign ministry of China stated it approved of its decision.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/05/24/burkina-faso-cuts-diplomatic-ties-taiwan-intense-pressure-china/|title=Burkina Faso cuts diplomatic ties with Taiwan after intense pressure from China|author=Our Foreign Staff|date=2018-05-24|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-05-26|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2147644/burkina-faso-cuts-diplomatic-ties-taiwan|title=Taiwan ‘won’t tolerate Beijing’s actions’ after it loses another ally|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-05-26|language=en}}</ref>
Burkina Faso's relations with its West African neighbors have improved in recent years.<ref>[https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/more-drives-ivory-coast-and-burkina-faso-together-apart Stratfor article titled "More Drives Ivory Coast and Burkina Faso Together Than Apart"]</ref> Relations with [[Ghana]], in particular, have warmed.<ref>Owusu, Maxwell. "Burkina". A Country Study: Ghana (La Verle Berry, editor). pp. 237</ref> President Compaoré has mediated a political crisis in [[Togo]] and helped to resolve the [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] conflict in [[Niger]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} Burkina maintains cordial relations with [[Libya]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} A territorial dispute with [[Mali]] was mediated by Ghana and [[Nigeria]], which has led to lessening of tensions between the two nations.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
Nineteen provinces of Burkina Faso are joined with contiguous areas of Mali and Niger under the [[Liptako-Gourma Authority]], a regional economic organization.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
Burkina Faso is also a member of the [[International Criminal Court]] with a bilateral immunity agreement of protection for the United States-military (as covered under [[Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court|Article 98]]).{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
==Bilateral relations== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="width:15%;"| Country ! style="width:12%;"| Formal Relations Began !Notes |- valign="top" |{{flag|Armenia}}||<!--Date started-->25 November 1992|| Both countries established diplomatic relations on 25 November 1992.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Austria}}||<!--Date started-->|| *Austria is represented in Burkina Faso by its embassy in [[Dakar]], [[Senegal]]<ref>[https://www.bmeia.gv.at/en/embassies-consulates/search-for-austrian-representations/]</ref> *Both countries established diplomatic relations in 1960<ref>[https://www.bmeia.gv.at/fr/ambassade-dautriche-a-dakar/relations-bilaterales/burkina-faso/]</ref>.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Benin}}||<!--Date started-->||
In September 2007, [[Economic Community of West African States]] (ECOWAS) intervened to attempt to resolve the dispute over two villages along the Benin–Burkina Faso border that remain from a 2005 ICJ decision. |- valign="top" |{{flag|China}} |<!--Date started-->26 May 2018 |See [[Burkina Faso–China relations]]
China and Burkina Faso re-established diplomatic relations on 26 May 2018. |- valign="top" |{{flag|Denmark}}||<!--Date started-->||See [[Burkina Faso–Denmark relations]] |- valign="top" |{{flag|France}}||<!--Date started-->1960||
* Burkina Faso has an embassy in [[Paris]].<ref>[http://www.ambaburkina-fr.org/ Embassy of Burkina Faso in France]</ref> * France has an embassy in [[Ouagadougou]].<ref>[https://bf.ambafrance.org/ Embassy of France in Burkina Faso]</ref>
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Georgia}}||<!--Date started-->10 October 2012|| Both countries established diplomatic relations on October 10, 2012<ref>[http://mfa.gov.ge/MainNav/ForeignPolicy/BilateralRelations/%E1%83%91%E1%83%A3%E1%83%A0%E1%83%99%E1%83%98%E1%83%9C%E1%83%90-%E1%83%A4%E1%83%90%E1%83%A1%E1%83%9D%E1%83%A1-%E1%83%A0%E1%83%94%E1%83%A1%E1%83%9E%E1%83%A3%E1%83%91%E1%83%9A%E1%83%98%E1%83%99%E1%83%90.aspx]</ref>.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Ghana}}||<!--Date started-->||See [[Burkina Faso–Ghana relations]]
With the coming to power of [[Thomas Sankara]] in Burkina Faso in 1983, relations between Ghana and Burkina became both warm and close. Indeed, [[Jerry Rawlings|Rawlings]] and Sankara began discussions about uniting Ghana and Burkina in the manner of the defunct [[Ghana-Guinea-Mali Union]], which Nkrumah had sought unsuccessfully to promote as a foundation for his dream of unified continental government. Political and economic ties between Ghana and Burkina, a poorer country, were strengthened through joint commissions of cooperation and through border demarcation committee meetings. Frequent high-level consultations and joint military exercises, meant to discourage potential dissidents and to protect young "revolutions" in each country, were fairly regular features of Ghana-Burkina relations.<ref name="cs">Owusu, Maxwell. "Burkina". ''A Country Study: Ghana'' (La Verle Berry, editor). [[Library of Congress]] [[Federal Research Division]] (November 1994). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/about.html]''</ref>
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Guyana}}||<!--Date started-->23 September 1987|| Both countries established diplomatic relations on September 23, 1987.<ref>[http://www.minfor.gov.gy/diplomatic-relations/]</ref>
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Iceland}}||<!--Date started-->|| Burkina Faso is represented in Iceland by its embassy in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]<ref>[https://www.government.is/lisalib/getfile.aspx?itemid=0eb3fa9f-6130-11e9-943a-005056bc4d74]</ref>.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|India}}||<!--Date started-->||See [[Burkina Faso–India relations]]
India and Burkina Faso enjoy warm relations. |- valign="top" |{{flag|Israel}}||<!--Date started-->|| Although Burkina Faso operates a consulate in [[Tel Aviv]], Israel has no diplomatic nor consular presence in Burkina Faso.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.embassypages.com/missions/embassy9234/|title=CONSULATE OF BURKINA FASO IN TEL AVIV, ISRAEL|website=embassypages.com|accessdate=15 April 2019}}</ref>
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Italy}}||<!--Date started-->|| *Burkina Faso has an embassy in [[Rome]] and honorary consulates in [[Florence]], [[Milan]], [[Napoli]], and [[Palermo]]<ref>[https://www.esteri.it/mae/resource/doc/2019/01/ldc%2031%20gennaio%202019.pdf]</ref>. *Italy has an honorary consulate in [[Ouagadougou]]<ref>[https://www.esteri.it/mae/en/ministero/laretediplomatica/rete-diplomatica-mappa.html?p=BURKINA+FASO&c=&cm=&ricerca=View+the+results]</ref>.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Ivory Coast}}||<!--Date started-->|| When [[Thomas Sankara]] came to power in 1983 relations between Burkina Faso and Ivory Coast became hostile as [[Félix Houphouët-Boigny]] was threatened by Sankara's revolutionary regime. That was one of the main reasons why [[Blaise Compaore]] launched his coup in 1987 killing Sankara and making himself president. Under [[Blaise Compaore]] Ivory Coast and Burkina Faso reestablished good relations and both countries supported [[Charles Taylor (Liberian politician)|Charles Taylor]]'s [[National Patriotic Front of Liberia|NPFL]] in their overthrow of [[Samuel Doe]]. They remain allies and are active trading partners.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Japan}}||<!--Date started-->1960|| Both countries established diplomatic relations in 1960<ref>[https://www.mofa.go.jp/region/africa/burkina_f/data.html]</ref>.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Kosovo}}||<!--Date started-->24 April 2008|| Burkina Faso recognised the Republic of Kosovo on April 24, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newkosovareport.com/20080424902/Politics/Burkina-Faso-recognizes-Kosovo.html|title=Burkina Faso recognizes Kosovo|work=New Kosova Report|date=April 24, 2008|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref> Burkina Faso and Kosovo established diplomatic relations on December 6, 2012.<ref>[http://www.ambasada-ks.net/fr/?page=1,8,65 Republika e Kosovës dhe Republika e Burkina Faso nënshkruan Protokollin për vendosje të marrëdhënieve diplomatike], Embassy of Republic of Kosovo in Paris, 2012-12-06 (in Albanian)</ref> Both countries enjoy excellent relationships. |- valign="top" |{{flag|Libya}}||<!--Date started-->||See [[Burkina Faso–Libya relations]]
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Malta}}||<!--Date started-->8 February 2008|| Both countries established diplomatic relations on February 8, 2008<ref>[https://foreignaffairs.gov.mt/en/Treaties%20Series/Documents/Burkina%20Faso%20-%20Establishment%20of%20Diplomatic%20Relations%20%20-%208%20Febraury%202008%20-%20Saviour%20F%20Borg.pdf]</ref>.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Mexico}}||<!--Date started-->1976||
* Burkina Faso is accredited to Mexico from its embassy in Washington, D.C., United States and an honorary consulate in Mexico City.<ref>[http://burkina-usa.org Embassy of Burkina Faso in the United States]</ref> * Mexico is accredited to Burkina Faso from its embassy in Abuja, Nigeria.<ref>[https://embamex.sre.gob.mx/nigeria/ Embassy of Mexico in Nigeria]</ref>
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Nepal}}||<!--Date started-->29 December 2017|| *Both countries established diplomatic relations on December 29, 2017<ref>[https://mofa.gov.np/foreign-policy/diplomatic-relations/]</ref>. *Both countries are [[Landlocked developing countries]].
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Netherlands}}||<!--Date started-->|| *Burkina Faso is represented in the Netherlands by its embassy in [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] and an honorary consulate in [[Rotterdam]]<ref>[https://www.government.nl/topics/embassies-consulates-and-other-representations/overview-countries-and-regions/burkina-faso/embassy-of-burkina-faso-brussel]</ref>. *The Netherlands are represented in Burkina Faso by their embassy in [[Bamako]], [[Mali]]<ref>[https://www.paysbasetvous.nl/votre-pays-et-les-pays-bas/burkina-faso]</ref>.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|North Korea}}||<!--Date started-->11 October 1972<ref>{{cite book |last1=Wertz|first1=Daniel|last2=Oh|first2=JJ|last3=Kim|first3=Insung|date=August 2016|title=Issue Brief: DPRK Diplomatic Relations|publisher=The National Committee on North Korea|url=http://www.ncnk.org/resources/publications/NCNK_Issue_Brief_DPRK_Diplomatic_Relations.pdf|access-date=22 February 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228074114/http://www.ncnk.org/resources/publications/NCNK_Issue_Brief_DPRK_Diplomatic_Relations.pdf|archive-date=28 December 2016|page=8}}</ref>||See [[Burkina Faso–North Korea relations]] |- valign="top" |{{flag|Russia}}||<!--Date started-->||See [[Burkina Faso–Russia relations]]
Diplomatic relations between Burkina Faso and the Soviet Union were established for the first time on February 18, 1967. After the breakup of the Soviet Union, Burkina Faso recognized Russia as the USSR's successor. However financial reasons has shut the embassies between the two nations. In 1992, the embassy of the Russian Federation in [[Ouagadougou]] was closed, and in 1996, the embassy of Burkina Faso in Moscow was closed. Burkina Faso has since re-opened its embassy in Moscow.<ref>[http://www.mid.ru/en/maps/bf/?currentpage=main-country Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs: Burkina Faso]</ref>
|- valign="top" |{{flag|South Africa}}||<!--Date started-->May 1995|| *Both countries established diplomatic relations on May 1995<ref>[http://www.dirco.gov.za/foreign/bilateral/burkin.html]</ref>. *Both countries are full members of the [[African Union]].
|- valign="top" |{{flag|South Korea}}||<!--Date started-->20 April 1962||
Establishment of diplomatic relations was on April 20, 1962, with visits in 1981 by Special Envoy of the President [[Roh Tae-woo]], in 1983 by Park Chan-geung and in 1984 by Kang Kyung-shik.<ref>http://www.mofa.go.kr/ENG/countries/middleeast/countries/20070804/1_24501.jsp?menu=m_30_50</ref>{{clarify|date=August 2015}} |- valign="top" |{{flag|Soviet Union}}||<!--Date started-->||See [[Burkina Faso–Soviet Union relations]] |- valign="top" |{{flag|Sweden}}||<!--Date started-->||See [[Burkina Faso–Sweden relations]]
Sweden is a major contributor of developmental aid to Burkina Faso. The [[Burkina Faso–Sweden Friendship Association]] was formed in 1986 to promote exchange between the two countries.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Turkey}}||<!--Date started-->|| *Since 2012, Burkina Faso has an embassy in [[Ankara]]<ref>[http://www.mfa.gov.tr/relations-between-turkey-and-burkina-faso.en.mfa]</ref>. *Since 2012, Turkey has an embassy [[Ouagadougou]]<ref>[http://www.mfa.gov.tr/relations-between-turkey-and-burkina-faso.en.mfa]</ref>.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|United States}}||<!--Date started-->||See [[Burkina Faso–United States relations]]
Relations are good but subject to strains in the past because of the [[Blaise Compaoré|Compaoré]] government's past involvement in arms trading and other sanctions-breaking activity. In addition to regional peace and stability, U.S. interests in Burkina are to promote continued [[democratization]] and greater respect for human rights and to encourage sustainable economic development. Although the [[Agency for International Development]] (USAID) closed its office in [[Ouagadougou]] in 1995, about $18 million annually of USAID funding goes to Burkina's development through non-governmental and regional organizations. The largest is a [[Food for Peace]] school lunch program administered by [[Catholic Relief Services]]. Burkina has been the site of several development success stories. U.S. leadership in building food security in the [[Sahel]] after the 1968–74 drought has been successful in virtually eliminating famine, despite recurrent drought years. [[River blindness]] has been eliminated from the region. In both cases, the U.S. was the main donor to inter-African organizations headquartered in Ouagadougou which through sustained efforts have achieved and consolidated these gains. In 2005, Burkina Faso and the [[Millennium Challenge Corporation]] (MCC) signed a $12 million Threshold Country Program to build schools and increase girls' enrollment rates. In November 2005, the Millennium Challenge Corporation selected Burkina Faso as eligible to submit a proposal for Millennium Challenge Account assistance for fiscal year 2006, making it one of only two countries eligible for threshold as well as compact funding. The Government of Burkina Faso is working closely with MCC staff to finalize its compact submission.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Uzbekistan}}||<!--Date started-->|| Burkina Faso recognized the independence of Uzbekistan on January 25, 1992<ref>[https://mfa.uz/en/cooperation/country/]</ref>.
|- valign="top" |{{flag|Vietnam}}||<!--Date started-->|| *Both countries established diplomatic relations on November 16, 1973<ref>[http://www.mofa.gov.vn/en/cn_vakv/]</ref>. *Both countries are full members of the [[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie]]. |}
